"step_by_step_thinking": "The question is about the type of Ig present in Gingival Crevicular Fluid (GCF). None of the provided documents mention GCF or gingivitis. However, one document talks about immunoglobulin (Ig) levels in patients with hemoblastoses and mentions different types of Igs such as IgA, IgM, IgG, and IgD. Another document discusses re-organization of the immunoglobulin kappa gene on both alleles and expression of Ig light chains.

Given this information, we can rule out IgD as it is not mentioned in any of the provided documents. The other types of Igs (IgA, IgM, IgG) are discussed in different contexts but do not provide direct evidence about which type of Ig is present in GCF.

However, a document on cytokine regulation of immunoglobulin secretion by neonatal lymphocytes mentions that all major Ig classes (including IgA, IgM, and IgG) were synthesized and secreted by peripheral blood lymphocytes. This suggests that multiple types of Igs may be present in the same environment.

Given this information, we can infer that IgA, IgM, and IgG are likely to be present in GCF, but there is no definitive evidence to suggest which one is dominant or if any of them are exclusively present.",
